text:
Analyzing JSP performance I've seen that some class methods are synchronized
with a synchronized (lock) {} clause. Other methods hasn't been synchronized.

synchronization is been "called" many times because methods are calling to
others. And this is a performance penalty. JSP Writer really is a "pseudo
writer" and not needs synchronization because it's not executed multithreaded.
We can take out the synchronization clauses.

Another performance issue is that we cannot configure wich are the default JSP
writer implementation for Tomcat, so we cannot extend the JspWriterImpl class.
Due to this issue we can define all methods final because executing final
methods is much faster than executing extensible methods.

text:
Although this change should in theory cause no problems, it is risky to
introduce any potential for thread-related problems this close to a release. 
Therefore, this performance improvement will be deferred until after Tomcat 4.0
final release, where we have time to thoroughly test it before inclusion in a
later 4.0.1 (or whatever) release.
Jasper 2 includes an optimized runtime, including a non synchronized writer.
